commentBody: Delightful!

Not sure what people saw online, but my puzzle in The Magazine was the Easy Sunday version. If I hadn't gotten the theme from the title, the note, and the revealer (noted in the note), the circles and scissors would have sealed the deal. I *solved* this puzzle before touching the grid, and I made no mistakes entering the crossing words. I liked the concept for the puzzle -- as I've remarked here, it's how I approach crosswords -- but I would have liked to have been at least a little bit puzzled trying to solve it.

YMMV
LSMFT
EOM

"You really didn't like that carpenter, did you?"
"No, my criticism was measured."

("Yeah, I guess it was on the level.")

This was frickin’ brilliant hands down.  Forget about the brilliant fun theme even, for those of you who don’t pay attention to grids look at the symmetry of all those long entries and consider what went into placing those and then finding fill that worked, admittedly  a little clunky in spots as the constructor admits but still decent. Loved the clue for ENDGAME
Barry, I hear you but I personally don’t think it was too easy even with the hints and without them most people would be totally lost.
One minor nit and two notes:
ALEPH is the first letter of the Hebrew alphabet but isn’t an A or even remotely like an A or even a vowel. 
As long as we are mentioning Rob REINER, if you liked  “This Is Spinal Tap” check out the sequel that just came out. Mixed reviews but I thought it was hysterical.
And to add to my growing list of crossword answers I  learned from “Survivor”—Lisa Weschel who played BLAIR came in second in Survivor: Philippines.  Also, Charlotte Rae who played Mrs. Garrett live in Milwaukee just blocks from where I grew up. (GO Brewers!)

Wow, this was fun! Took just the right amount of puzzlement. 
As usual, I found little stories in the theme pairs:

The orange juice hoarder spent two whole minutes gloating MINE ALL MINE.

I drafted a business letter to my gardening partner griping why he had only grown two pounds of FENNEL BULBS.

GALILEO GALILEI gave an elegant lecture to his doubters explaining what it meant that his water clock had collected two gallons.

I lost the bet, so we WENT FIFTY FIFTY on the price of the two feet of raffle tickets.

Gaelic, Russian and Italian history are not my strong points.  I first came across Measure Twce... while watching This Old House, probably back in the 80's.  And then I mentioned it to my father -- it was new to him, too.  We weren't accomplished woodworkers (obviously) but we tried.  Admittedly on simple projects.

I'm trying to remember some of those This Old House shows, but all I can bring up are portions of Home Improvement, a show I watched but seldom.  Not the same thing at all.

The puzzle was a pleasant experience, both for the puzzle and the This Old House memory.
Oh, this was a good one! Not too hard, although I did struggle with the scissor ones for a while. Thanks for a fun end to a weekend of solving. Y’all enjoy your Sunday! Thanks, Michael!
loved the puzzle too much. three in one. never saw or read any comments before. all adds up to fun.

Caitlin, thanks for the column and especially for including the origin of BENEDICT. I got it from the crossings, and guessed that it was an allusion to a literary or historical figure, but you saved me some googling.
My Diary of a Crossword Fiend review: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/10/11/sunday-october-12-2025/#ny

Fun puzzle, and wow! two tricks! But I was done in by typing in ONCE in the rebus square.

17D: I knew there was some crosswordese word for doofuses in Canada, but as it's not a term I ever hear in actual conversation, I had to rely on the crosses. 

On the topic of Canadianisms ..... not many people say "eh" either.

Excellent work! I always admire puzzles where something difficult to find (in this case, phrases that contain the word “once” but also a unit of measurement — repeated twice within the phrase!), can be executed so elegantly. Kudos!
I cannot find the Saturday, October 11, 2025 Crossword There's always a line-up of the week's puzzles by day showing which you have done and which you have not. Has the NYT changed its puzzle format?
I'm so used to misdirection that instructions meant to be taken literally threw me for a loop (at first).
Very witty. I liked it.
What score would I give this? 10! 10! I hope another of Mr Schlossberg’s crosswords is so[✂️]rtified for publication!

Fantastic. And I'm fine with OLIO, Michael Schlossberg. I print it out so, because of the scissors graphic, the PDF was crammed onto one page in like three-point font, which makes me crazy, but it went quickly and was super satisfying to solve. Brilliant concept.
Never heard the term Old Scratch. Tough puzzle for me.

Absolutely fantastic. 3 payloads for me:

1: learned a nifty new adage
2: cozy aha! when the 'measure twice' clicked
3: fireworks when the 'cut once' clicked

For all you crossword creators out there, I wonder if you could work Shakespeare's "Measure for Measure" into a crossword.   
Not quite sure how it would work, but I think it has potential. 

tc
Amazing construction. Really enjoyed!!
22:18. Theme really opened it up, impressive fill though mostly

Any puzzle with COLIN Firth in it is okay by me. Amazingly, to me at any rate, I figured out all the moving parts to this one all by myself. Was able to plunk the revealer in with no crosses, though the little scissors were something of a hint.  
Finally, I'd like to thank the movie National Treasure: Book of Secrets, which was recently on cable, for teaching me about the RESOLUTE DESK. Knowledge is everywhere.

Wonderful puzzle! 

Not really a quibble, but here’s an observation about a slight inconsistency: two of the “measure twice“ clues use repeated words: FIFTY/FIFTY, and MINE/MINE, and a third is almost verbatim, with GALILEO GALILEI. But the fourth is a different format with FENNEL BULBS, which I actually see is a higher level of craft than the blunt repetition — but in any event it is a slight inconsistency.

I’m more of a measure once cut twice guy, but I enjoyed this puzzle.  The construction was quite clever.  Getting the revealer made the puzzle flow smoothly.  I was ok with the circles, because otherwise I never would have noticed the “measure twice” aspect of the puzzle, but the scissors showing where to cut “once” made the solve easier than I would have liked.
Carpentry keeps me ship fit and trim! More than I can say for me belly. It's my peg leg, I tell ye! Argh!
Very clever puzzle, and the best Constructor Notes in a while.

A Sunday puzzle with a theme that's not a set of groaners? Wow! So it *can* be done 🤷🏽

I mostly enjoyed the solve. I figured out the theme on my own even though the imperial measurements used in it are largely alien to me. 

I struggled with the fill in two or three places and had to resort to several lookups, especially around the MERC spot. That entry alone caused me problems. To me Merc is a Mercedes - that's what we call it for short in Polish (we just pronounce it [Merts]), and I've been hearing it in English-language car shows for decades, too. I'm familiar with the brand Mercury, and I guess I had an inkling it became defunct, but my mind just could not accept Merc could be anything other than a Mercedes. I did not know the etymology of ABBOT, either, or any type of sax other than alto. Neither was I familiar with SPINROOOMS. All that wreaked havoc in that area for me. I was so confused I had to turn to Google for help.

Elsewhere I had WILe for the coyote, and the American sport cross did not help me in spotting the mistake. I wasn't really comfortable with that square though so I changed the e to a Y and got my gold star.

It was not a bad puzzle. My struggles were Andrzej-specific.
Quite appreciate this puzzle's theme. Wish it had run before I tried my hand at installing wood flooring in our master bedroom.

I’ve been thinking about other examples for the measure twice side; there are obviously plenty but many wouldn’t be very interesting; “mi” for miles, “mm” etc. I think the constructor did a good job of finding challenging and interesting ones even if they were a bit repetitive. But here’s an another fun one although a bit obscure: “Third book in an L Frank Baum series (4 tablespoons)” —OZma of OZ.

At first I saw only a single scissors on my screen, did not recognize it and I thought the screen had been somehow scratched.  IMO a genius construction which must have taken a while to plot out.  Unfortunately or fortunately, that usually works to simplify the puzzle - certainly true in this case.
And for MERC it gave me pause too; as a Marvel fan I would have appreciated “____ with a Mouth (nickname for Deadpool)”—short for mercenary.
So the missing “once” across does not work on the down entries?

I guess there still may be a testosterone molecule or two floating around in my blood stream.

I was very proud of beDtiME for [When mating typically occurs].

And I've played a whole lot more chess lately than...well, you know.

That was really a great trip all around.  Loved the puzzle, loved the tricks, loved the constructor notes (my construction instructions are always terrible, too, failing to take into account my total idiocy when it comes to anything...uh, real, I guess).

I take a little pride in doing the "math" in my head about which letters are cut out.  Partially that's because I'm too lazy to get up and find a pencil and piece of paper to write the phrase out.  But I did (finally) figure out it was O...N...C...E and then the dope slap...of course!

I suspect we're going to have some complaints along the lines that they should have accepted rebuses with the ONCE, even if it doesn't work for the down.

So I shall gird my loins.  I probably would have anyway, because loins really do need a good girding, but now I definitely will.
Loved it. Who else tried BED TIME at 118A? Hands  up!
That was a lot of fun! Plus, I learned what a Koan is. :)
I never heard that phrase before but I soon figured out what was going on with the circled letters and scissors. From that, I figured out the phrase. Fun!

A relatively quick solve today, but it had me a bit perplexed for a while until I encountered 63A, which both enlightened me and caused me to groan at the wordplay. I had resisted the impulse to consider a rebus, because of the scissor icons, so I just filled things in from the crosses for the first two themers, then when the "AHA" came, it made the last three a little simpler to fill in.

The crosses helped in a few spots, and I had the initial E for 118A so that I eventually figured out the chess reference. Old Scratch was actually a gimme, though it's probably been over 50 years since I encountered the term. Shout out to Aidan Deshong for his Minesweeper puzzle for making 23A another gimme.

A very pleasant diversion; thanks, Doc!

I learned the phrase, "Measure twice; cut once," while hanging out with my grandfather in his woodshop. I also saved him from cutting off his finger once. Is there an adage for that one?

Fun puzzle!

I don’t know why, but this one just didn’t work for me.  I usually enjoy the theme puzzles with clever twists but tonight not so much. I got about 90% done without solving the trick then had to use wordplay and a couple of Google look-ups to finish.

This was totally in my lane. I am in the midst of building a magazine box for group photos with my husband and my cousin for her son’s wedding. My husband literally reminded me this morning to MEASURE TWICE, CUT ONCE 🤣 I’m enjoying this construction project with them and expanding my carpentry skills. All in all, I thought the grid was NEATO. Thank you, Michael 📏📏✂️
too cool for school.

Woo-hoo! I got this one! Took a while, but figured all the tricks, found phrases, filled circles, had fun! Although on my phone, the scissors were faint and the light parts "implied" that letters were missing. ONCE I got that, cruised home and thought I'd try my hand at commenting. 😊  Greetings, all!
Measure for measure, a very fair puzzle I enjoyed beyond measure!
Ugh.

Interesting that the constructor makes an extensive apology for using Olio, which didn't bother me at all, but ignores the real glaring chunk of rank glue that is "Dam Up".  That little bit stunk up the whole puzzle, which was otherwise smooth and satisfying.

A fun ride.  Clever cluing.
You know what’s worse than OLIO?  “Mansplained”
Not easy, but thanks for the challenge.

The puzzle was tailor-made
A credit to the setter trade
A little treasure 
Made to measure
Bespoke and top grade

I confidently put in RING for "Rock band" (like a band on your finger that might hold a rock or gem) and congratulated myself and the setter for being so clever.

But no.
Very fun Sunday morning.

Thanks, Caitlin, for the link to the Great White North! That was a blast from the past. So funny, eh? I remember saying "ya hoser" a lot.

Terrific puzzle, many sticky areas for me. Yes, lots of glue, but worth it for the theme. I found ONCE difficult to remove in my head, which was cool.
Very playful. I had fun.

A Sunday that's fun, funny, intelligent, well constructed and devoid of all the usual things that plague me (personally).

Michael Schlossberg, you get a big 😘 from me. (Lucky for you I'm far too old for you.)
Usually not the biggest fan of solutions that aren’t proper words on the grid… but this was clever and fun, the trick was consistent, and satisfying to solve. Nice one!
Never heard of a bari sax I had alto in there for ages, then bass but got there in the end. Theme was very good and I really enjoyed the clues for bad dog and toro

I got the trick very quickly, unusually for me! Exceptionally cleverly constructed. I didn't really notice the words in brackets, too busy solving the clues, but it was an extra fillip. 

I haven't ever seen or heard 'quarts' used since I had to learn as a child:
4 gills - 1 pint
2 pints - 1 quart
4 quarts - 1 gallon

Gills were used in pubs to measure whisky - traditionally one sixth in England and one quarter gill in Scotland - a long time ago!
Fun solve and so very clever! (Also wise advice for the DIYers!) Really enjoyed this one; the theme was perfectly executed—which must have been tough to pull off!

I’m not sure which I enjoyed more, the puzzle or the constructor’s self-deprecating comments about OLIO.

This was a pretty smooth solve for me, save for the altoSAXES entry that really slowed me down in the NE quadrant. As the wife of a hobbyist woodworker, I am very familiar with the “measure twice, cut once” adage— although sometimes, it really helps to measure three times. Trust me. (That also applies to sewing projects, which are more in my wheelhouse.)

I’m grateful for the explanations for BENEDICTS and ENDGAME, because those had me totally confused. Proud of myself for getting BAD DOG right away, though. (I’ve had experience.)

Those scissors were cool.  They acted as phantom rebus squares containing ONCE.  You could only see that word in your imagination rather than crammed into a square.  A symbol in a crossword grid between squares? – I don’t ever remember seeing that before.  Just a brilliant stroke, IMO.  High props, Michael!

Also, props, sir, for pulling this off at all.  Are you kidding me?  Nine theme answers, all with lengths in double figures?  Four instances of theme answers abutting for four squares?  Finding four ONCE-embedded answers to be symmetrical with the four double-circle answers?  Wow!

I’m guessing you measured more than twice in making this work, Michael!  

In your notes you lamented over the handful of gluey bits in the grid, but, IMO, those were easily outweighed by the stellar strokes that created a most lovely riddle-filled solve.

A famous ZEN KOAN is “What is the sound of one hand clapping?” But what your puzzle evoked from me, Michael, is the sound of two.  Thank you!

I’m surprised to be the first to point out the Shakespeare misquote. “Gild the lily” is erroneous. The correct phrase refers to painting the lily; it’s the already gold thing that gets pointlessly gilded.

The Resolute Desk clue provides a perfect case in point: the once-elegantly austere and now tastelessly gilded office in which it sits. 

Sorry for the gilt trip.

This was fun and, as they say, breezy. A real relief from the very challenging, but also fun, puzzle yesterday. I don't know if I've ever heard a carpenter say MEASURETWICECUTONCE, but it's certainly a familiar adage. Follow that rule and you can avoid saying, with regret, "I cut it three times, and it's still too short!" Got it without any crosses. It took me until I finished the whole thing to figure out where the ONCEs went; I suspected lurking rebuses. And when I got to 120A and I had DO_K I was looking for our friend the DOOK, but no. By coincidence, I was just watching the Great White North guys last night. I read that Geddy Lee, from the band Rush (is that right?) had donated his collection of 400 autographed Negro League baseballs to the Negro League Baseball Museum. (I doubt that I'll ever get to either Kansas City, but if I do I'd like to go.) Anyway, the connection led me to the time Mr. Lee helped Bob and Doug out on their hit single. https://youtu.be/8Jm4LoOaAWI?si=i5ye64Vsk8pwtL-V Take off, eh? Great start to a chilly Sunday. Thanks!

1) The puzzle was brilliant 
2) On the topic of the note, when I initially open the puzzle the “i” in the upper right corner was blinking, yet no note appeared.  I thought the blinking means “read the title page precisely because there an attached note,” but I guess not.  Now I’m wondering if it always blinks and I usually ignore it. Since I can’t wait and check over the next few Sundays, will someone explain? (Sorry in advance if it was explained elsewhere).

As a hack carpenter, I always thought the adage should state: 
Measure five times, cut once, sand for an hour. Works for me!

Amazing tricky puzzle!
the scissors kept moving a few squares when I zoomed in and out on my android screen before I got the trick, so I had to close and reopen several times, adding yet a third trick to the puzzle

Wanted to point out how the measurements could be considered in four different contexts:  distance = feet, weight = pound, volume = gallon, time = minute. 

Wonder if this was intentional?

tc

I print out the puzzle, so I've learned just recently, thanks to a hint from, I think, Steve E., to check the newspaper version, especially on Sundays and Thursdays, because the regular .pdf omits any of those things that often make the difference in solving a puzzle. I'm not sure I could have finished it without having done that for this puzzle. Those scissors don't appear in the regular .pdf, were an instant alert as soon as I saw them. And that helped me get the theme very quickly, both parts of it. 

But it was tough going, since I have something wrong with one of my eyes and had to solve it using a big magnifying glass. Sunday print is SO tiny. But today is my birthday, so it was a really nice way to start the day. Thanks for a lovely gift, Michael!

As for the revealer, I learned it years ago. My only woodworking was in building a huge dollhouse and a lot of dollhouse furniture, so I always had that phrase in the back of my mind. Also helpful when I'd hem my own pants.

I loved SCTV when it played back in the early 80's, so somehow I managed to pull HOSERS out of my ....whatever.  Also, unlike most American college students, when they went south, I went north, and spent almost every spring break in Montreal or Toronto, so I heard "eh" quite a bit. Too bad I didn't stay there, as I had wanted to during that terrible era. And want to again.

Just look at how tasteful that Oval Office is, and compare it with how garish and gaudy and tawdry it is now.
I interpreted Benedict as Benedict Arnold - betraying batchelorhood for marriage. Got the answer so that’s what counts!

I knew there was a reason I added Pilates to my “don’t try these exercises” list: clearly it’s too easy to bother with.

The black squares in today’s puzzle are almost the same pattern as the holes in one of our lamp shades, thanks to a bad dog. Probably the lamp shades in the Rolo Office are more resolute.

An enjoyable Sunday puzzle.
Oof, nice spoiler for Project Hail Mary. Glad I read the book already. A big part of the fun of the book was trying to figure things out along with the protagonist.

Fan. 
Flipping.
Tastic.
Puzzle.

Olio and all.
I really enjoyed the puzzle...how amazing that  the constructor had the scissors and the circles. I don't mind olio..but didn't like yeah so.
Just finished Saturday. Thankfully, as it took twice as long as average, wasn't sure I was going to get it.  Sam Ezersky's reputation for tough puzzles remains intact.

What a concept, to conceive a concert of words concealing ONCE, as if from a sconce-lit brain.  I toast you, Michael, with a limoncello!





Et tu, emu.
What a concept, to conceive a concert of words concealing ONCE, as if from a sconce-lit brain.  I toast you, Michael, with a limoncello!

It took me a bit to figure out the theme but once I did my solve went fairly briskly and I finished roughly 30% under my average time. The theme reminded me of the time 20 years ago when I was selling my house and decided to replace the baseboards on my own, after getting a carpenter’s bid on the project. Getting the length right, given the necessary angle cuts often meant measure twice, no three times, no four times, cut once, oops, measure five times…you get the idea…

At any rate, I ended up admiring this puzzle quite a bit and enjoyed a lot of the clueing…37A “Rock bands” for SEAM; 118A “When mating usually occurs” for END GAME; 29D “Cycle at night” for REM.

Again, given our present circumstance I felt a twinge for anything connected to governance…71A “Biohazard regulator” for OSHA and especially 70D “‘Resolute’ item in the Oval Office” for OAK DESK. The photo illustration for the Wordplay column made me nostalgic for saner times.
The first time in recent memory where I got the theme early enough for it to help me fill the grid. Great puzzle.
For a few days now, the choice of left-handed in printing does not "stick" - I must re-enter it each morning. As of today, the left-handed print prints right-handed.

Felt like a large themed Friday.  Not any real chewy answers except Ashkola - today I did learn. 

I found it fun the perfect amount of time to spend on it.  With a couple of brains to get my brain to catch up, it was a relatively smooth puzzle.  

Coke back soon Mr. Schlossberg.

Wonderful puzzle, but I especially love Sclossberg’s riff/rant on OLIO. OREO mansplaining was foreshadowed by the two million times that my parents told me about OLIO and food restrictions during WW II. The message was that we had butter and thus, I had nothing—ever—-to complain about. Dadsplaining, I guess, though they both said it.
Anyone else annoyed that 89A didn't really nail the theme?

Great puzzle but my nitpick is “sweets” for HON. I couldn’t get off the other kind of sweets and thought they were talking about ho HOS. Not knowing who Scratch was I had no idea. But for HON why isn’t it “sweet” singular? Who says “my sweets”?! Very enjoyable puzzle overall. Got the scissors trick from the jump with the juice clue, a rarity for me.
I love when a puzzle feels like a Rube Goldberg contraption. Does anybody know if this is the same Gary Larson who does the Far Side comics.

I'm pretty late because my eyeballs have practically dropped out of their sockets from the strain.  Now that I've completed this TOTALLY WONDERFUL puzzle, I see NO reason whatsoever why I wasn't permitted to print on two pages.  It would have speeded things up, prevented mis-identification of numerals, and prevented this headache that has started up...  

So, so clever and fun!  That said, it actually was not that difficult, but when a puzzle is this entertaining, ALL is forgiven.  

I had roasted FENNEL BULBS in the restaurant at Hotel Alfa in...um, 1971 ...along with chateaubriand and a lovely red wine.  SWOON.  

I got MIN-MIN first, and then TO WHOM IT MAY CRN completed the SATANic double whammy.  
The single Nit:  not ONCE did anyone call his BARItone SAX a "BARI."
Had some fun with BIG DESK, THE DESK, OLD DESK...tsk.  Why not walnut?

I must go check on the source of the "Men who marry later in life," because there's one sitting across the breakfast table from me right now.  Adieu.

I was stuck for ages with a bass sax, moving forward only once I allowed myself to peek at today’s article. 

Ah yes. BARI sax. 

The other four letter low sax starting with BA- 😆
Every dictionary I’ve consulted this morning says that religious title comes from Aramaic! Fun puzzle.

I enjoyed the puzzle.  Agree that the graphical flourishes (and unnecessary parentheticals in the measurement clues) made things a bit too easy for my taste. But every now and then it’s nice to have a single-cup-of-coffee solve!
I didn’t get it, I didn’t enjoy it, a slog for me. But I’m happy you’re happy
Also an adage heard early on in surgical training in OR
Fun puzzle.  Ingenious is the only word that keeps coming to mind.  Had me puzzled for a bit at first - but the aha moment came quickly enough.  Definitely a great Sunday.  Thanks tons for this one.
So who else had that poster of the white Lamborghini Countach on their bedroom wall? Most definitely the DREAM CAR of the '80s.
"Measure twice - cut once" is better than the way I learned it, "I cut it twice and it's still too short."
Delightful Sunday puzzle! Loved the constructor notes, as well. Thank you!
Definitely not a fan of the book spoiler. Statute has not yet expired on that one.

Omg! This puzzle had me in stitches.

Starting with HOSER as any self respecting Canadian should get on the first pass, with no crosses. But then REM for cycle at night, ICE for pretty cool stuff and BAD DOG for Out damn Spot (I was looking so hard for a Shakespeare reference!).

I was really hoping bull in a Chihuahua shop would be typo, but TORO works as well.

Overall, a fresh, lively, enjoyable puzzle that had me grinning throughout, and served as the perfect palate cleanser for yesterday.
As a stage magician, I learned MEASURE TWICE, CUT ONCE the hard way.

Enjoyed this one a lot. Took me much too long to realize what each pair of scissors literally stood for. Kept thinking that I had to cut along the lines marked by the scissors and physically rearrange portions of the grid. Which would have been very NEATO had it been part of the solution!

More so than several recent puzzles, this one had an excellent theme that (to me) didn't negatively impact the fill.

My only nit is "When mating typically occurs" for ENDGAME. Replacing "typically" with "sometimes" seems to boost the clue's accuracy without weakening the misdirection at all. Checkmates typically occur in the MIDDLEGAME, at least in any universe of chess games that I'm familiar with. They almost never occur at the tournament level, and elsewhere very few chess contests ever reach the ENDGAME. Happy to be corrected about this.

Help. I have full paper subscription, Android.  I used to be able to get to the daily column, and these comments, by tapping "crossword" then "read about," that no longer works, all I get is the puzzle itself. I have to go to a separate Google search on word play column that's how I got here. Anyone else have this problem, email to support on Friday was unanswered. I uninstalled and reinstalled the app and that didn't help.
To the constructor I say, Bravo!!!  Wonderful Puzzle!
I should just learn french i guess, since its often the last clue to fall. THE?

42:58, 48:04 faster than average. Also, 7 Sundays in a row! This kind of streak is ok too!

Felt like an extended Tuesday. Enough crossers to avoid naticks. The mating clue was my favorite, rutting season notwithstanding. I had SNIDER for quite a while even though I knew it was spelt SCHNEIDER. I let the crosses gently move me to a different Rob. It’s important to be kind to oneself, that way.

After all these years of doing these puzzles, all living in general, I am apparently the only one that never heard the term ZEN KOAN. I clearly heard many of them, but never the term.  Learn something every day.

ZENKOAN/ZYNGA was the last to fall for me. Had to run the alphabet. That's how it goes sometimes. Now I know. 
Batten down the hatches, east coast peeps!
Maybe it’s just because I’m under 50, but I found the cluing on this one to be really challenging and obscure in spots. Made for a pretty painful fill.

This one was an unalloyed joy. I got the first part of the theme very quickly but those cut marks took awhile longer. I left a hole to the right of each of those until I realized that what was needed was not a rebus. An anti-rebus?

It took longer than my usual although I was never stuck. Just extra time steadily uncovered its delights. A perfect Sunday!

I loved that the apparent primness of the 4A clue was belied by just going ahead and saying the word, alright, already! in an answer that crossed it.

Does anyone know why the Puzzle Week ends on Sunday instead of beginning on Sunday, as related to the Statistics page?  Wouldn't beginning the puzzle week on Sunday make much more sense since it is considered the first day of the week in the US and it is usually the most time consuming puzzle?

One would be more likely to see a whole week's worth of puzzle stats (Sunday to Saturday), eliminating the current practice of switching over for the week on Sunday afternoon when some, including this person, are just sitting down to solve the Sunday.

Oh my gosh! Was at parents’ and did this in ink.
My mistake was I forgot about BARI SAXES and wrote Bass Saxes. My face is red. I have been in concert and stage band. Enjoyed the puzzle!

Not a single complaint with this one.  Though it was quite a slog for me, not once did I feel stumped and helpless.  A word dawning here and there led to a succesful completion.  My brain is still catching a breath as this is what a crossword is supposed to be.

Good fun.  Thanks.  The BENEDICTS/BLAIR "B" was the last to fill as I had no memory of either.   

The theme brings to mind an incident when we were repairing a deck.   I was up on the scaffolding shouting down measurements to the guy running the saw.  Every single piece came up a quarter inch short.  Finally I had to climb down and asked to see his tape.  The tang at the end had been bent from it being dropped.  I treated him to a new tape measure.
So very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very, very tedious.
Would that make them Benedict Carnals? Fun puzzle!

Wow, what fun!

This was a joy to solve and felt like just the right difficulty. I managed to figure out the theme about 1/3 of the way through (and loved it). I knew some clues that stumped others (like ZENKOANS), but others were tricky (e.g. DYSON). I was totally unfamiliar with this meaning of BENEDICT, but being one myself, I was really happy to learn it!

Did anyone else think the clue for 29D, "Cycle at night?" seemed like a missed opportunity to mirror the clue for 37A, "Rock band?" That was the only thing I think might have slightly improved and otherwise stellar puzzle!

31 Down- should be amended to say “Core-strengthening Exercise” removing the word Pilates. No where in Joseph and Clara Pilates repertoire is there anything remotely like TOETAPS. Or, keep that Clue and with the same number of spaces how about ROLLUPS, HUNDRED, TEASERS…
-going on 27 years teaching the Pilates Method.

Fun puzzle.  My only nitpick (minor) is that three of the four scissor clues were “CONCE” before cutting once.  Felt like the fourth one should have also been the same or if not all four should have been different.  I kept thinking: What in the world is a stancon ceremony?!?
Awesome LOL constructor notes. The riff on cherry cola Oreos, mansplaining… Loved all of it… and, of course, the puzzle. Thank you.

Great puzzle but I feel like it should have counted as a solve for keeping the rebus with ONCE in the squares. I get that the point is to “cut” the once out, but it’s not like  the across words worked without the rebus. Seems like either/or should have worked for the app to count it as a solve.
My carpentry skills are more MEASUREONCECUTTWICE.  Fun puzzle!

my problem became that I didn't figure out how to enter the letters in the boxes that left out ONCE. I tried x/once and xonce and oncex and once/x before I figured out you had to leave the ONCE out but it really belonged IN for one direction.
I find the puzzles very hard to read (I have poor vision) and these kinds of shenanigans are aggravating. There should be ONE consistent way to enter letters that are different in the two directions.

🚩🚩 SPOILER ALERT🚩🚩

Ugh, Ugh, UGH! I lost a 70-day streak because I just couldn't or didn't figure out not to enter ONCE as a rebus in the four relevant cells, that ONCE had already been cut.
Really liked the puzzle AND Michael's notes. Threw oreos right in our faces and I didn't even care!

I found this perfect for a Sunday and a breeze after Saturday that I had to finish this morning to keep my streak. I could only start it in bed last night before drifting off. 
A good theme and an easy revealer for this carpenter that made parts of the puzzle easier to solve once I was looking for double measurements. I am impressed by the way ONCE can be hidden so well in various phrases. I am lucky that one daughter played Bari Sax in high school and the other dated a young man that wrote a book on Zen koans.

After you cut the rebus in half, print out the puzzle, then fold it in fours, spin it like a top and watch it bloom into a flower, pick the petals of the flower, then eat them. In a few days you'll pass only the circled letters which will spell out PICK ONE GIMMICK.
This was FUN!

I thoroughly enjoyed this theme. I can't imagine how difficult it must have been to pull off. And the notes on OLIO were the icing on the cake 😂

This was tough!!!!!!! I did like the theme but frankly the "measurements" aspect in the non-thematic clues felt really random and I kept wondering why they weren't more directly related to the ONCE answers. Way too much going on for a lizard brain like me!

I *love* this puzzle.  The way the theme is included in two different ways, the elegant clueing, nothing forced ... just everything about it.  To me this is the perfect Sunday crossword.

This was a very clever theme, that left me wanting more: If only, Michael, you could have found a way to represent the "measure twice" part of the proverb with as much trickery as the "cut once" part! Exactly how one might do that, though, I have no idea. And so, we get a *very* tight set of four entries, which nevertheless could easily have been solved without the [measurement] parts of the clue. Tight, as in: [Satisfying my comfort food craving, as for cherry cola Oreos, quaintly [.002m]](15) Funny how it takes four overdubbed tracks to cover Kurt, Krist, and Dave: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Bf8pqZOB5U&list=RD3Bf8pqZOB5U&start_radio=1 Now that you've mulled on this: YU[MM]Y FOR MY TU[MM]Y Michael, your themers are much better than mine!

I am very tired tonight. So I'm going to save what I haven't finished for tomorrow. But there is so much going on that it's exhausting. I'm still trying to figure out all the cutting and pasting. When I get a night's sleep, I'll come back. In the mean time, I just want you to know I like doing crossword puzzles. I don't get bored with them. I could do them all day. You don't have to impress me with all sorts of complications. Barry, what you are calling the Note is confusing people I think.  I would call that Will Shortz's intro to the puzzle.  Caitlin always opens her column with that intro so those of us who don't solve on paper or look at the "Magazine" version PDF the puzzle can read it.
What online solvers consider a NOTE occurs when they open up the puzzle in the app and they see the page that has the constructor's name and the puzzle's title and sometimes, very rarely, there is also a NOTE, which explains something further about the puzzle.

You said Will's intro helped give the theme away for you.  Not sure it would have helped me. But then, as I say in my main post, I didn't need help with that.

@SP
its exceedingly a-adjacent and it certainly is always a vowel in all its incarnations when its being used rarely as a silent letter (as in the hebrew word for "sin").

@Matt
The Hebrew, Greek, and Roman alphabets all share a lot of territory. (Why do you think it's called an /alphabet/? Aleph-bet》alpha-beta》alphabet...) Long sequences of equivalent sounds in the same order are shared among the three. 
Look up the history of the /shapes/ of letters, which I found fascinating. You can see the history of Western Civilization in the movement from picture to pictographs to letters.
Hebrew has five letters with different terminal forms, Greek has one, and Roman has none. So you'd expect it to be shorter, no?
No! Hebrew is a trim 22-letter alphabet (excluding those terminals) while English, in its florid magnificence, has 26 letters. When it wandered away from the Mediterranean, it picked up northern variants like W as well as retaining superfluities like C and K. Still, I like an alphabet with a little meat on its bones!

@Esmerelda Bob and Doug Mackenzie of Second City introduced America to both hosers and eh, or at least to me and my friends. Here is an example: https://youtu.be/u3niShPaKFY?si=BLJwmln457CACDpD

@Esmerelda

I have known many Canadians and Buffalonians and can assure you that I've heard "eh" used a lot.  From the Montreal location, I'm guessing that it may not be used in the Francophone community.

On reflection, probably the first time I heard it  I was in high school in NYC and our English teacher was from Saskatoon.  He used it often enough that it became part of our vocabulary.

Still think of you, Mr Murray Edwards.  Hope that you're still around as a centenarian.

@Al  in Pittsburgh
Eh is not used at all by francophones (the equivalent in Quebec French would be "tu" stuck into a phrase, not as a pronoun but as a question mark). But you're right about the francophone influence -- Montreal anglophones don't talk the way Canadians from other regions do, and they use a different vocabulary. Like in the US, there are big regional differences in speech across the country (spend some time in NFLD for that). So maybe elsewhere, you get a lot of eh's. Or maybe the eh just stands out more, because that's what Canadians are expected to say.

@Tony

Um, while I agree this was artfully constructed, the two types of gimmicked phrases were entirely separate, at least as far as I can tell.  (The "but also" in your comment makes it sound as if both gimmicks were present in a single phrase.)

From Wikipedia:

_______
The coyote's name of Wile E. is a pun of the word "wily". The "E" stands for "Ethelbert" in one issue of a Looney Tunes comic book.[17] The coyote's surname is routinely pronounced with a long "e" (/kaɪˈoʊtiː/ ky-OH-tee), but in two cartoon shorts, To Hare Is Human and Rabbit's Feat, Wile E. is heard pronouncing it with a diphthong (/kaɪˈoʊteɪ/ ky-OH-tay). Early model sheets for the character prior to his initial appearance (in Fast and Furry-ous) identified him as "Don Coyote", a pun on Don Quixote.[18]
______

@Lewis

An art professor once told me that, by now, “everything’s been done before,” and that trying to come up with something novel was a fool’s errand. In the century-plus of crossword puzzle-making, given the constraints of the grid and a language written in only 26 letters, you’d think the same  would be true of new ideas. 

And then, like today, you get surprised. 

A very nifty Sunday puzzle.

@Sam Lyons
I’m with you in principle, but a hundred years isn’t nearly long enough for me to let go of my prescriptive persnicketiness. 

My own speculation about why “paint” disappeared is that the whiteness of lilies is not now seen as a virtue, perhaps because of another figure of speech – lily white – that originated in the Black community to represent racial segregation. 

Also, stock phrases tend to shrink, even when it destroys meaning. Everyone now says, “The proof is in the pudding”, which makes no sense. The original was, “The proof of the pudding is in the eating”, which is coherent but way too long for modern patience.
@Post Mortem I always associate "Gild the lily" with Chaucer, and by that I mean Paul Bettany says it in A Knight's Tale when he's offering to fabricate Heath Ledger's patent of nobility

@Post Mortem

As a recovering prescriptivist, one who finally wearied of the Sisyphean toil, I admire your resolve [smile]. 

I suspect that our bias for gilding the lily over painting it is still Shakespearean in origin, i.e. that back when many high school graduates could still recall the full line from King John—“to gild refined gold, to paint the lily”—they simply fell prey to our human unconscious preference for combinations that share or balance phonetic features. In this case, phonesthetic reduplication favors the ‘il’ of gild echoed in the ‘il’ of lily. 

With “the proof is in the pudding,” I agree that it’s somewhat nonsensical in modern usage, but that’s only because we think of pudding as a dessert. In the 17th c., when the original, “The proof of the pudding is in the eating,” was first penned, the pudding in question would have been a sausage; encased, presumably, in that shiny shrink wrap sausage lives in. So, ironically, our modern shortened “the proof is in the pudding” would still have worked for a food whose outer appearance gives little clue as to what’s on the inside. 

Language and psycholinguistic phenomena: Who needs Netflix, right?

@Post Mortem

I don’t dismiss Netflix—well, not categorically. I do partake on occasion. But I do hope that “Netflix and chill” isn’t really a euphemism for the act of love… is it? 

I have three nieces and two nephews who are being raised without smart phones or tablets of their own and without tv sets in the house. I’m hoping their act of love one day, be it euphemistically or literally, will involve books. 

Maybe even quoting from King John. I’m an optimist.
@Post Mortem. Thank you from a septuagenarian trying to keep up with slang.  But I am still not sure why “Netflix and chill”. unless staying at home=opportunity.

It is a really interesting concept—I often ask the younger generation if they know of some gimmee, for me, adages, or slang, and find that they have not translated for them.  “Me…twice”, for example, I heard from my father and father-in-law regularly, both of whom owned and used saws. @Sue Eilers

The theme revealer clue almost always hints how to enter them. Sometimes extra letters are outside the grid, sometimes they can be found inside a different answer either above or at right angles. Or, in a black hole grid, they may appear somewhere else in the grid altogether. Whenever there are extra letters, I leave them out altogether until I am sure there actually is a rebus involved. If things aren't working, I keep rereading the revealer clue until the penny drops. One time I finally came to these comments to figure it out.

The fun for these kinds of puzzles, for those of us who like them, is to use the clue to figure out the trick.
